captions.text:
On those cold, rainy days when you forget
your rain jacket or umbrella and you want

to stay as dry as possible… should you walk
and spend more time in the rain? Or should

you run, which means you'll be smashing into
more raindrops from the side?

Assuming you haven't been fully soaked yet
and you aren't jumping into puddles, the answer

is simple. As you move out of the way of one
falling raindrop, you move into the way of

another. So the amount of rain hitting the
top of you is constant, regardless of how

fast you're going. Alternatively, you can
picture that the raindrops themselves are

stationary and you (and the earth beneath
you) are moving upwards through the rain!

And since the volume of a parallelepiped (that's
a 3D parallelogram) doesn't depend at all

on its slant, then no matter how fast you're
moving horizontally the same amount of rain
will land on top of you each second.

Now, if you're not moving, the rain from the
top is all you'll get. But if you ARE moving,

you'll also run into raindrops from the side
and you'll get wetter. So in any given second,

you stay driest by standing still, and the
faster you move the wetter you become.

But if you're trying to get from point A to
point B, then standing still won't do you

much good. And en route from point A to point
B, the total amount of rain you run into from

the side has nothing to do with how fast you're
going - just like how a snowplow will plow

the same amount of snow from a stretch of
road regardless of the exact speed it drives.

In the case of running through the rain, you
can figure that out using parallelepipeds
again.

So over a given period of time, the same amount
of rain will hit you from the top, regardless

of how fast you're going. And over a given
distance, you'll hit the same amount of rain

from the side - again, regardless of how fast
you're going.

So your total wetness is equal to the wetness
per second for rain from the top times the

amount of time you spend in the rain, plus
the wetness per meter for rain from the side
times the number of meters you travel.

So to stay driest getting from one point to
another, you should try to minimize the amount

of water falling onto you from above. And
quite simply, that means getting out of the
rain as fast as possible.

title: Is it Better to Walk or Run in the Rain?

So realistically the best way to avoid getting wet is to slant yourself 
forward with proportion to how fast you are moving, to make it so water 
only lands on your head and shoulders, and the rain already in front of you 
reaches the ground before it hits your front. This would also mean not 
moving your legs. Basically walking like you're on an invisible segway.﻿

comments.author: SHAHEER AWAN

comments.text:
You still have to factor in the amount of rain left that can be produced by 
the cloud and movement of the cloud(s). If the cloud moves at the same 
speed as you in the direction you are running, standing would be a better 
option to avoid raindrops. If the rain clouds are not moving very fast and 
there is a vast amount of clouds incoming from any direction, it'd be best 
to move or run to a new destination. (Preferably a shelter from the rain) 
Though the wetness per meter may not change between running or standing, 
there is a certain point where you are completely soaked and the excess 
wetness does not really soak into your clothes or hair anymore and then the 
wetness is not an issue. When that time comes, if you were running, you'd 
have actually accomplished some distance rather than remaining stationary 
like a statue waiting for the rain to subside when you get equally 
drenched. ﻿

comments.text:
I don't buy this at all. Even with my own experiments I've seen that that 
walking slowly I get less wet than if I ran. 

Raindrops don't fall equally and predictably, they are random droplets. By 
running faster you increase the probability of hitting more droplets, than 
if you were slower. Running is better only if the distance to be covered is 
short or if the rainfall is very heavy.﻿

comments.text:
If I am walking in the open air and a heavy rain comes (and expected to 
remain for an hour), I normally don't measure how much wetter I get for a 
certain period of time.  I just want to get myself in the shade.  So I have 
to run for cover.

Technically, running for cover is best.  As a common person, who cares how 
much water lands on you for a measured time.  The common person will do 
something for the least water (if the person does not want to get wet).﻿

You will actually get wet both top and side depending on how fast you move, 
the more wet you will get from the side. If you stand still, only rain from 
the top will hit you unless there's wind. As you move 1 step, you just move 
into 1 more drop of rain onto your head and due to the movement you move 
horizontally into 1 drop of rain that already had moved past your body 
length and would have landed on you already if you stood there to begin 
with, but you moved into it.﻿

comments.text:
This is not the whole story.
What if the rain is falling at 1/10 its normal speed and i am running at 
10x my normal speed?
Less rain would falling per second and my exposure to that rain would be 
reduced as well.  I will get the same amount of wet from horizontally 
colliding with the rain, but less rain will fall on me, thus i will not be 
as wet.﻿

time decreases﻿

comments.text:
This is really inaccurate. The rate at which you hit raindrops from the 
side is also constant. 
Imagine: If you move infinitely fast, you hit all of the raindrops on your 
way to the destination, but nothing hits you from above.
As you slow down, more hit you from above, but the same number from the 
side. 

Once again, misinformation from Minute Physics. It's almost as if he comes 
up with these videos in a minute as well.﻿

comments.text:
Most people are saying that if you run faster you have less chance of 
getting sick because you spend less time in the rain.

Ah! But you forget! The majority of people on this planet claim that they 
are uncoordinated or unfit, so the faster they run, the more likely they 
will slip and fall (also the less traction due to the water increases this 
risk), which would result in a gash or other form of open wound, which will 
allow any 'bad' things in the rain (or from where you fell) to personally 
enter your bloodstream, increasing the chances you will get sick! Also! The 
time spent on the ground writhing in pain and your own shame is spent not 
moving out of the rain, which increases the overall time you spend getting 
wet! 

Ha! Take that you rain un-enthusiasts! ﻿
